speaker: freddie hoyt

speaker: robyn semien
utterance: Bob walks up minutes later.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So there actually is a place at Town & Country where they keep score of who has sold what. It's in Freddie's office, the general manager's office. It's a whiteboard with each person's sales for the month to date on it. Every car or truck that they've sold is represented by a little magnetic rectangle that's roughly the size of a 9-volt battery. Everybody calls these chips. And the different colors of the chips stand for different models of cars and trucks.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And throughout the day, salesmen come and they hover around the whiteboard, seeing where everybody stands. And generally, everybody is shooting for at least 15 sales a month. At 15 sales, your commission for the next month jumps from 20% to 30%.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: There's also a bonus of $600 when you hit 10 cars, $250 if you sell seven cars in the first two weeks of the month. There's money you get directly from Chrysler, and that could be anywhere between $50 and $250 per car. Mid-level salesmen here and Town & Country make around $60,000 a year. Top performers are closer to $100,000. Most of that is commissions and bonuses.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: The number one salesman at Town & Country is always the same. Some months, he has twice as many sales as whoever's in second place.

speaker: peter possas
utterance: I've been doing this 28 years. This guy is one of the best I've ever seen.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: That's salesman Peter Possas standing at the board. It's the middle of the month.

speaker: peter possas
utterance: He's got 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8-- 15, two pending. 17 cars. Unbelievable. This guy's a born salesperson.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: All the veteran sales guys at Town & Country say these things about this guy. He also happens to be the youngest salesman of dealership. He's 28. Jason Mascia. Reporter Sean Cole followed him around.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Jason stands out from everybody else on the sales floor in pretty much every way. He's taller than everybody else and way more focused on his appearance-- always a full suit and tie, double Windsor knot, gelled hair. He's handsome. And he isn't just the best seller at Town & Country. He's one of the best sellers of Jeeps, Chryslers, Dodges, and Rams in America.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: So I'm going to go on my login here. And then, boom.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: He showed me this internal Chrysler company website that ranks all the salespeople.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: I'm talking thousands of people. You see this national number? There is 29,000 salespeople in the whole entire country.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: And you're--

speaker: sean cole
utterance: You have a shocked look on your face.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: Yeah, because I look at it and I say, that's freaking crazy. You know what I'm saying? You would think a guy that's in this business for 15 to 20 years should be doing that stuff.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Jason's barely been in this business for four years. When I met him in the last weekend of October, he had already outsold everybody for the month, including a guy who's been doing this since Jason was a toddler. But he says he's not competing with the others. He's competing with himself.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: I'm trying to excel. I have my own goals that nobody would even know about. You know what I mean? So I'm like my own little celebrity in my own little body.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: As we're sitting there talking, he pulls out a piece of paper and starts writing down everything he's saying as he says it. He always does this. I have 10 pages of notes from this interview-- his notes.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: So most of the salespeople at Town & Country are shooting for 15 to 20 sales in a month. That's considered a solid performance. And Jason is not satisfied with a solid performance.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: There's a number that I really want to hit.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: He writes down that number and circles it and then moves on.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: And I would love to just achieve-- I have achieved 30 cars several times.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Writes down 30, underlined "several." That is, 30 cars a month.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: All right? So I've done that enough to say I could do it. Now I'm trickling--

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Writes down 30, plus sign.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: --30-plus.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: For October, hoping to finish the month in the mid-30s somewhere. But Jason's own personal Olympic goal?

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Say what this number is that you wrote down.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: This is 40. 40's a big number. You know what I mean? If you could hit 40 cars, that's more than a car per day. That's sick. That's crazy, especially when you're selling cars. You know what I mean? It's not like I'm selling suits.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: What took me a while to understand is how Jason sells so many cars, or what he's doing differently than everybody else. And we asked pretty much everybody else this question, but their answers were kind of generic. He's a good-looking kid, good personality, got the gift of the gab. Even Jason sort of defaults to truisms when you ask him what his secret is. Says he treats every customer like he would want to be treated.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: But as much as you can figure out anybody in less than a week, I think Jason's success is due to three basic attributes, three characteristics he has that have propelled him to the top. So I'll go through those now.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Number one, constructive delusion. Now, Jason knows that a certain percentage of customers, depending on the month, will walk away from him without buying a car. Of course that happens. And yet, paradoxically, he enters every negotiation full in the knowledge that it will not happen. As we're sitting there, he drew a picture of a very lopsided hourglass with a line across the skinny part.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: You know, are you looking at it half empty or half full? You know what I mean? Are you optimistic or are you-- what's the other word?

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Pessimistic.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: Pessimistic.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: To Jason, the glass is not half empty, and it is not half full.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: Me, I'm always at 100.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: It is 100% full.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: Yeah, it's full. And you're like, what the hell?

speaker: sean cole
utterance: No, it's not. There's only half of the water there. No, no, no.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: No, it's full to me.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: But for someone who barely possesses the word pessimistic in his vocabulary, that's not always how he seems on the sales floor. More than any of the other sellers, Jason's anxious.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: I'm going crazy right now. I'm biting my nails. Biting my nails off because I'm stressed.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Biting his nails, hovering around the manager's desk. It's like the dealership making its quota is personal to him.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: Jason-- and this is number two on our list of attributes. Jason doesn't just want to sell cars. Jason needs to sell cars. Case in point, I watched him work this one deal, a lease on a Jeep Liberty. He played it totally cool at first. But when the haggling started, it was like someone had clamped a set of jumper cables to his ankle.

speaker: jason mascia
utterance: And between 375 and 329 is 46 times 39 is another 1,700. But you've got to put the value point on it. You now have a sunroof.

speaker: speaker 1
utterance: Really?

speaker: jason mascia

utterance: Two hours later, he's already crashed. It's like that deal never happened.

speaker: jason mascia

speaker: jason mascia

speaker: sean cole
utterance: So that's two. And then the third and final attribute that I think has led Jason to being the top seller of Town & Country, ABC. Always Be Calling your girlfriend to say, baby, I just have a couple more things to take care of and then I'll be home.

speaker: gena
utterance: We got into an argument about it last night.

utterance: Oh, no.

utterance: This is Jason's girlfriend, Gena. She stopped by to say hi to him at the shop one of the days we were there. The night before that, he had come home too late and screwed up their dinner plans. Gena says they're always running into a store five minutes before it closes. She's imposed a no-work-talk-over-dinner rule, but Jason always has just one last thing to tell her about something that happened at work.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: And they've only been together a year, so they can both still laugh about it, at least with me. But of course, working long hours can threaten everything else in your life, and the entire business of selling cars is built on working long hours, working weekends, when more customers come in, coming in on your day off, when the store needs to meet its quota. And the damage that can do is all around Jason.

speaker: sean cole
utterance: The sales guy in the cubicle next to him, Peter Possas, told me managing a sales team at a dealership in Florida is what led to his divorce.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: In the second half of October at Town & Country, sales stay slow. And going into the last two days of the month, they still have so many cars to sell that when Freddie sees me arrive in the morning on the next to last day of the month, knowing what it is that I'm about to ask him, he starts laughing.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Oh, boy. Here we go. We're behind 16 cars for the month so far. And that's not good. That means I need 16 cars between today and tomorrow.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Here's how hard that number is. Freddie tells me that he only expects 15 or 16 customers to show up in the store each day, which means that to get to his number, he's going to have to sell a car to every other person who walks in the door.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And what my fellow radio producers and I witness over the next two days-- OK, some deals do go through, but it's almost a catalog of all the ways that a car deal can fall apart. There were the obvious ways. A young woman doesn't get approved for her car loan. A father and son promise to come back tomorrow to sign the papers and take the car. They never come back.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: But there turn out to be all sorts of other ways that a car deal can implode that we had never imagined or conceived. For instance, Bob T.

utterance: Bob, please see Rich in Finance. Bob.

speaker: ira glass

utterance: Basically, what happens is he told a couple that their new car is $2,000 cheaper than it actually is. They found out the truth while talking to Rich, the finance manager, and kind of hit the roof.

utterance: Why am I thinking I'm getting screwed here?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Bob T was also surprised. He himself thought it was $2,000 cheaper. The finance manager, Rich, tells Bob T that Bob T should have, first, better understood which rebates the couple's qualified for. That's where the mistake was. And second, he should have explained it to the couple.

speaker: rich
utterance: You left the middle out. You left the meat of the sandwich out.

speaker: ira glass

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Here's how it happened. Scott had sold a red Jeep Grand Cherokee to this customer, this guy who came in with his dad. They left a deposit. And the little magnetic chip that they use to keep track of the sales, the one for this car, nobody had put it on the whiteboard in Freddie's office, the board that keeps track of who sold what. speaker: ira glass
utterance: It's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. Today's program is a rerun. We did all the reporting for today's show a few years ago during a month, October 2013, when car sales were strong, up over 10% what they were a year before around the country. That's 1.2 million new vehicles sold that month. But that doesn't mean that every dealership in every town had an easy time of it.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And today on our program, we watch one dealership, just one, on Long Island-- Town & Country Jeep Chrysler Dodge Ram is what it's called-- as they try to make their sales goal of 129 cars for the month. If they sell 129 cars, Chrysler is going to pay them a big bonus, and they need that money to be in the black for the month. If they just sell 128, bupkis.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So it's 9:15 in the morning on the 31st. How many cars do you got to get?

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Nine.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: God help us.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: God help us. I don't know. It's going to be-- it's going to be hard.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: On a good month, he would start the last day with just two or three cars to sell. Nine. That's crazy. And it's Halloween, which means that lots of potential customers are going to be out with their kids today.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Everybody is so tense that it's not even 10:00 in the morning and a customer walks out without buying a car.

utterance: No, we're done. Sorry, but we're done. I came in to make a deal, and that's not what I was expecting.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: Thank you. Have a good night.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And one of the managers, Sal, has this edgy little conversation with the salesman who let him walk out.

speaker: sal lanzilotta
utterance: What happened to that guy you were working?

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: He left.

speaker: sal lanzilotta
utterance: You've got to stop doing that, bro.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: How do I stop doing that? You don't help. You got a meeting--

speaker: sal lanzilotta
utterance: You didn't even come up here. How am I supposed to help? Where's my crystal ball, in the shop? Do it again, you're following him.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: Let's do it. Let's do it right now.

speaker: sal lanzilotta
utterance: Go ahead. Pack up. Go.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: He doesn't go.

speaker: sal lanzilotta
utterance: Un-fucking-real.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: The morning's still young when I find Freddie in his office selling a car to himself-- a loaner car for the maintenance department to lend out to customers who are getting their cars repaired. He's allowed to count that in his sales total.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: So now we only need eight more. See, it's starting to come together already.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: By mid-afternoon, he'll buy a second loaner car for the dealership. Back in February, Freddie bought a Durango for his wife to make the number that month, replacing a car that he had just bought a year before for her for the same reason.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Joe? What's the story with your cars?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Freddie is calling Joe Monti, one of the guys who runs the used car side of the business at Town & Country. Joe has got his own goal to hit for the month that is separate from the new car goal. 70 used cars. That's the number Freddie set for him.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Is any of them going out yet or what? What are we doing?

speaker: joe monti
utterance: They're all going out, boss.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: OK, but how come none was even delivered yet? I'm still sitting at six.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: Yuri's delivered the Chevy Trailblazer.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Hold on. What?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: While we were at Town & Country, we asked everybody what it would mean for him or her personally if the team did not make its sales goal. And it was actually this guy, Joe Monti, over in used cars, who gave us the best picture of that. Sarah Koenig hung out with him for a while.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Joe's particularly stressed out this month. Half the time I'm with him, it feels like he's fighting, even with customers.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: Nobody's giving you a runaround, Jessica, OK? Yelling and screaming and being rude and threatening is not going to get you anywhere. The car-- the car-- the car is a great car.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Next fight, he calls a woman in the back office who he thinks ratted to Freddie about a deal she didn't like.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: Theresa? Well, can you pick up the phone? Nails could get done later. Why did you run-- why did you run to Freddie? Why did you run to Freddie and tell Freddie about a Chrysler 300? Whose conversation? Why were you talking to Eddie? First of all, if a manager writes off on a deal and signs it-- she hung up the phone.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: I'm sort of surprised anyone would have the balls to fight with Joe. He's a big man-- 350 pounds. Large and in charge. The day I meet him, he's wearing a gray tracksuit,

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: but what I quickly find out is that he's wearing a tracksuit because it's his day off. He's supposed to be at his son Mike's football game against Malvern. He hasn't been able to catch an away game all season, and he took this one Sunday off to do it. It was important to him.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: For so many years, he wasn't around enough for his kids. He's working all the time. Joe knows Mike will be looking for him in the stands right about now. And he's not going to be there because he's here at the car lot.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: We're a little shorthanded, so I've got to be here, which is not a problem. Listen, if I'm making money, I'm making money. Just it's a catch-22. You're missing a game, but that's the car business.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: That's the car business. I'll make it up to him later.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Yesterday, Joe was late to his mother-in-law's surprise 70th birthday party. And last week, he was late for his own mother's 60th. The used car side of Town & Country is supposed to sell 70 cars by the end of the month. That's Joe's version of the 129 on the new side.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: When I first met Joe, used was at 35. At stake is Joe's big year-end bonus. Joe wouldn't tell me the amount of the bonus, but he made it clear it's very, very nice. Down-payment-on-a-house nice.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Since he fell so behind the last couple months, this month, October, is make or break for Joe. He's got to get to at least 70 cars if he wants any hope of reaching that bonus by the end of the year. And it's not looking good. 20 years in the business, Joe's never seen a stretch this slow for this long.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Joe blames it mostly on Hurricane Sandy. A year ago, tens of thousands of people lost their cars all at once. And they got new ones all at once. So now, a year later, tens of thousands of people are out of the used car market who normally would be buying and selling right now.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: We had two weekends in a row we sold one car.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Oh, my god.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: For two Saturdays and two Sundays, and we sold one car.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: In the whole weekend?

speaker: joe monti
utterance: The whole weekend. The whole two weekends, we sold one car. There was days we didn't see a customer.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Joe goes outside to do an appraisal on a Nissan Quest. This also gives him a chance to have a cigarette, one of about 40 Parliaments he'll smoke today. His wife and kids get on him about the smoking. He's got six kids. Six kids-- two are grown, four of them still at home.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Joe's the only breadwinner in the family-- always has been-- so it's all on him. Even in the best of times, Joe's a worrier, like his grandmother. He's 42 years old, but he looks older. In the past year, he's gained about 80 pounds.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: In the parking lot, Joe throws away a half-smoked cigarette and then looks over the Nissan Quest. Tires are so-so. Needs some detailing. It's got a cracked taillight and a bad CARFAX report, meaning it's been in an accident. $2,000 is fair for this car, Joe says. It's what these are going for at auction.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: He tells me the customers are going to want at least $2,500, but there's no way he can do that. $2,500 is just too much. He heads back inside.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: $2,500, that's everything.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Instantly caves.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: That's what I will do.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: He needs the deal. They shake on it.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Joe was about 22 when he started in the car business. He had a baby at 18-- his son, Joseph-- and then four more kids-- Dean, Chris, Michael, and Adriana, plus his stepson, Louis.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Joe himself was one of five kids. His mom raised them by herself, no dad around, no money. He moved around a lot. With his own kids, he's the uptight parent, the one who doesn't laugh enough, the one who hammers them about consequences. He wants his kids to fear his wrath but also to know he loves them. Sometimes, it's tricky for him to balance that or even to talk about it.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: I have a good relationship with my children. I didn't have a father. So it's hard to do something when you don't know how to do it. Sometimes you don't know how to do-- I'm like a manly man.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: So I love them very much, but I don't know how to sometimes show it to them. I kiss them. I hug them. But you know what I'm saying? Something that I have to adapt to. But that's it. They're good. They're good kids.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Joe wants his kids to have more stability than he had growing up and a better standard of living. For 16 years, they all lived in a big house in Smithtown in a fairly wealthy neighborhood. And Joe says there was pressure there. Some other kids at school had fancy clothes and extravagant vacations, blow-out sweet 16 parties. He didn't want his kids to feel less-than, so he made sure, within reason, that they had what the other kids had.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: But three years ago, he left Town & Country for another job at a Toyota dealer, and it didn't go well at all. He lost-- well, he says he lost everything. But in any case, it was a lot of money. They sold their big house in Smithtown and moved to a smaller house in Levittown, about five minutes from the dealership. And in a lot of ways, Joe's glad about that. It's made them closer as a family, he says.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: But he's also trying to work his way back up. He'd like to be able to buy them all a bigger house, give everyone a little more room. That's why he's so worried about this bad stretch of business and about getting that bonus.

speaker: sarah koenig
utterance: Toward the end of the day, his son Mike calls. Joe's already spoken to the coach about how the football game went.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: Two sacks and two tackles. That's great.

speaker: mike monti
utterance: OK. Wait, Dad.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: What?

speaker: mike monti
utterance: Do you think [INAUDIBLE] to your job so you can give us some money so we can go get something to eat?

speaker: joe monti
utterance: Yeah. All right. I'll be home in probably, hopefully, like 20 minutes, and I'll give you money to go out to eat.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: All right. Bye.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: Every one of them. And it's hard to say no. You try your best. When you're doing well, it's no big deal, and you can take care of them. And then there's just doing well to where you're making it by.

speaker: joe monti
utterance: What is it? Today's October. What's going to happen in a couple of months when my son's get ready to leave for college? Am I going to have the money?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: It's mid-afternoon on the new car side of Town & Country. So what do you do all day on the last day of the month when you need to sell everything you possibly can? Well, instead of waiting for customers to come into the store, you call up any lead you have and try to close deals right over the phone if you can.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: One of the salespeople, Lori, does this with a previous customer. Jason also sells to a guy he knows over the phone. Peter gets a lead from a cop upstate that he sold a Durango truck to. The lead is a friend of the cop's, also a cop, who wants the same deal his friend got. Peter gets him on the phone and says he'll give him the deal for two reasons.

speaker: peter possas
utterance: One of them, you were referred. And the other one is you're an officer of the law, and we respect that over here, big time, just so you know.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Of course, this leaves out the third and main reason for the great deal that he's getting-- they need eight more sales by 9 o'clock. And the cop ends up buying his Durango for $2,214 less than the dealership paid for it. Even after finance charges and holdback and all the other ways they make money, they still lost on this one.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Ditto this guy, Richard Massana. He was going to get an oil change this morning and stepped in on a whim and they showed him numbers way lower than any other dealer that he'd been to. Richard called up his wife to let her know, hey, surprise, we're getting a new truck. On his test drive, he still seemed amazed at what was happening.

speaker: richard massana
utterance: Who would have thought Halloween, buying a truck? I never thought it would happen.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: His payment will be $425 a month. The salesman says later that it should have been $525, but it's the end of the month. Turns out, yes, it is true that you do get a better deal at the end of the month at Town & Country-- at least any month that they're struggling to make their goal.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: When you actually look at the numbers, the cars that they sell on the last two days, the average deal actually loses money versus the deals that they make at the beginning of the month, where they made about $900 per car. OK, for car people, I'm now going to say these words. I am factoring in everything they made on financing and warranties and extras and holdback and the 1% they get from Chrysler on every car when I make that statement.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: I am not factoring in any money that they would get if they hit their number and get their bonus from Chrysler. That would add about $500 per car, which still does not give them a huge profit per car. It used to be a lot higher. But today, because people research prices on the internet, profit margins on new cars are lower than what they used to be, not just here at this dealership, but everywhere in the car business.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: The owner of Town & Country told me that he used to make $500 more per car, and each salesman made more per car. Now they all have to make it up in volume. So it's more of a grind, a harder job with tighter deals and less reward.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And if you're wondering, car dealerships make less profit than other businesses. A recent study by an outfit called Sageworks found that car dealers end up with less than $0.03 on every dollar they make as profit, which is less profit than furniture stores, office supply stores, restaurants. Lower than pretty much everything but grocery stores. When car dealers say that they are not making a killing, on average, it's true.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: At some point during this last day of the month, one of the deals that they had been counting on falls through. Mike Lester's sale of a red Grand Cherokee. But turns out that's no problem for the dealership because Scott has a customer who wants that exact same truck. You remember that deal the day before, where two salesmen sold the same car to two different customers. The mortician? It's that salesman and that customer, and the salesman, Scott, is very, very happy. And the only bad news about all of this is what it does to Mike Lester's sales total for the month.

speaker: mike lester
utterance: That drops me down to 14.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: 14 sucks because, like I said earlier, 15 is the magic number. 15 is where the serious bonuses and commissions kick in. Most of the guys count on getting those.

speaker: mike lester
utterance: It could add up to big money.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: But then, Scott, whose customer is now going to get the red Grand Cherokee, Scott realizes what this means for Mike and says to Mike--

speaker: scott froehlich
utterance: Wait, is that your 15th car?

speaker: mike lester
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: scott froehlich
utterance: You take the chip. Give him the chip. Switch it around.

speaker: scott froehlich
utterance: And split it with me.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Now Mike will get the credit for the sale. He's at 15 again.

speaker: mike lester
utterance: OK, yeah. Love you, Scott.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Scott kisses Mike on the cheek. Producer Brian Reed witnesses all this.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: So you're at 15 now?

speaker: mike lester
utterance: Yes.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: Did he owe you one, or?

speaker: mike lester
utterance: No, but we always help each other out, especially on the last day of the month.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: How do you feel?

speaker: mike lester
utterance: Excited.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So amidst anxious salesmen and salesmen literally running to the desk or to finance, there is one salesman who is a model of calm. Even his cubicle is different from everybody else's. There's no swag. There's no pictures of family. There are no good luck charms. It's bare. The salesman, his name is Manny Rosales, says he doesn't like the distractions. One of our producers, Brian, who you just heard, got to know him.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: Manny is 58, born in Peru. He has gray hair and glasses. One morning at the showroom, he gestured cryptically for me to come over to his desk, as if he had a secret to tell me. Turn that off, he said, pointing to my tape recorder.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: I explained that I was a radio reporter and I needed to record whatever he was going to tell me for it to be useful, but he wasn't having it. He seemed unimpressed by our little radio story. He said my colleagues and I were like fishermen who had no idea what we were angling for. We had no focus. We were just casting blindly.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: Manny, I soon learned, is a man of many metaphors. I put down my recorder. The thing you need to be paying attention to, he said, is the negotiation. The salesman is the tiger, and the customer is the deer.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: The tiger has to eat, and you can't eat if you don't kill that deer. He moved his right hand up and then clamped his fingers around his own neck. You have to go for the neck, he said. But if you try to kill him too early, the deer will wake up and run away.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: As the day went on, I kept trying to get Manny to let me record him, but he wouldn't. Instead, he'd come up to me while I was interviewing someone else, point to his head very deliberately, presumably to his brain, give me a knowing look, and then walk away. At one point, we found ourselves facing each other at his desk. He asked me if I had read the greatest book ever written about car sales. I don't think so, I told him. What is it? The Art of War, he said, by Sun Tzu.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: Sun Tzu, as you maybe know, was a military general and strategist in ancient China. The Art of War is his magnum opus, where he lays out his tactics for how to succeed in conflict. And though Sun Tzu was writing about actual war, the book has become well known in business and sales circles. It's kind of like The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People, if that had been written in the fifth century BC on individual strips of bamboo.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: So I went to the bookstore and bought a copy and then headed back to Town & Country.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: Manny, how are you, sir? Can I show you the homework I've been doing?

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: Please.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: I handed him my copy of The Art of War, which I'd marked up with notes about its relevance to car sales. I could see why Manny felt that it spoke to his profession. Lines like, "draw them in with the prospect of gain," "take them by confusion" seemed especially on point.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: How far are you?

speaker: brian reed
utterance: I finished it.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: You finished it? OK. I want to ask you a question. What have you learned?

speaker: brian reed
utterance: What have I learned? Well, I'm here to learn some more.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: And I was in. For two days, Manny took me under his wing with my recorder running and became my sales sensei.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: Manny's kind of an unusual car salesman because he has no affection for cars at all. If a customer asks him how much horsepower a car has or how quickly it can go from 0 to 60, usually he has to look up the answer or go ask a coworker. He has no interest in that stuff. So instead, Manny developed a way to sell the customer using a different approach.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: The psychology. How you penetrate his brain.

speaker: film narrator
utterance: Sun Tzu says all warfare is deception.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: To help me understand this-- how to penetrate the brain of one's opponent-- Manny showed me a couple of movies on YouTube. One was a re-enactment of the Second Punic War in the third century BC, Hannibal's campaign against the Romans. Manny wanted me to pay attention to one battle in particular from that war, the Battle of Cannae.

speaker: film narrator
utterance: One of the bloodiest ever fought.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: At Cannae, Hannibal's troops were vastly outnumbered. He had about 40,000 men versus Rome's army, which had roughly 85,000.

speaker: hannibal
utterance: The Romans will have the confidence that comes only with greater numbers. We'll present them with the unexpected and watch them fall apart.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: See, that is the secret. Present the unexpected.

speaker: hannibal
utterance: Our forces will be arranged like this.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: The details of Hannibal's strategy are a bit complicated to go into here. Manny had to draw me a diagram to help me get it. But let's just say it involves an unusual troop formation that made the Romans think they were gaining ground when really they were at Hannibal's whim.

speaker: hannibal
utterance: At this point, the Romans will think they have won. Let them taste victory.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: We're watching this, remember, on a laptop on the showroom floor. Customers are milling about, checking out the new cars, as Hannibal's mercenaries and cavalry encircle the Romans and trap them for good.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: And now the killing has started.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: So how does Manny use this to sell Dodge Chargers? Well, just like Hannibal would, he presents the customer with the unexpected.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: What they expect is for the salesman to be pushy and try to coerce them into buying a car at a certain price. So Manny does the opposite. He acts as if he doesn't even want to sell the car. He agrees with the customer, uses a similar tone, repeats words the customer says. If someone comes in and says he's just there to browse, not to buy, that's totally fine, Manny will say, and he'll back off.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: The idea is to make them believe that he's doing everything from his point of view. So he's thinking he's playing his game.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: But he's really not?

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: Absolutely not.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: What game is he playing in reality?

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: My game. Simple. Simple.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: Manny gave me an example of this that he'd executed a few days earlier with a customer named Julio, who was looking for a Jeep Grand Cherokee. Julio runs warehouses for a living and negotiates for his company, so Manny knew he'd be a formidable opponent. Julio told me later that he'd already visited seven other Jeep dealerships by the time he got to Town & Country and was calling and texting with another three.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: When he sat down across from Manny, Julio made the first offer, $36,000. The Jeep was listed at $45,000, so Julio's offer was absurdly low. Julio knew it was unrealistic. He expected Manny to say no way, that he could never give it to him for that price.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: But then listen to what Manny did instead.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: I said, all right. If I can sell it to you for $36,000, are you ready to do it right now? Show me the money. Where's the credit card?

speaker: brian reed
utterance: Where's the credit card. Manny says this was the key move, the unexpected move.

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: Because they never thought I would say yes. Suddenly, they don't know what to do or what to say. They get confused. He cannot back up because that's what he said to me. If you give me $36,000, I'll buy the car.

speaker: hannibal
utterance: At this point, the Romans will think they have won. Let them taste victory.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: So he pulled his credit card out?

speaker: manny rosales
utterance: Absolutely. He gave it to me. And I said, all right, let me take the offer to my manager, even though I knew that we cannot do it.

speaker: brian reed
utterance: After days of negotiation, Manny ended up scoring this deal. Julio paid $40,000 for the Jeep, which was low. The dealership lost money on the car. But after it was all over, Julio told me that this move, when Manny pretended to take his low offer seriously, he said, without that, he would have walked out of Town & Country immediately, which would have meant no sale, nothing towards the monthly quota.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: By 4:00 PM, the hustling in the showroom is paying off. Chips are going up on the board in Freddie's office. Even one of the guys in the back rooms is pitching in-- a finance guy, Terrance Kelly, TK. He's reaching for the phone.

speaker: terrance kelly
utterance: So basically, the numbers are down. They need all the deals. So they made me call my niece in Las Vegas, believe it or not. She's been trying to buy a car anyway.

speaker: katie
utterance: Hello?

speaker: terrance kelly
utterance: Hi, Katie.

speaker: katie
utterance: Hey.

speaker: terrance kelly
utterance: How are you? I have you on the speakerphone.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: TK's got 34 nieces and nephews. Katie is his goddaughter, though, so he keeps a special eye out for her. At the time that this was recorded, the rest of the family didn't know that she was pregnant, though he did. Even though he did not know, until he picked up the receiver and started filling out the forms for the car sale, her fiance's last name.

speaker: terrance kelly
utterance: OK. Charles Parker? You're getting married to somebody with the last name of Parker? Oh, Barker. Oh. Is he related to Bob at all?

speaker: terrance kelly
utterance: What does he do, by the way? I never asked you. Ooh. HVAC company? Nice. I like that. Well, as long as he's happy. You're in the right area for air conditioning, I guess.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: The dealership is selling the car to Katie below cost at a $900 loss. And TK is going to end up spending $1,200 of his own money to ship the car out to her in Las Vegas. And this? This is the sale that puts him over the top. This is the 129th sale of the month.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Just a few minutes before 5 o'clock, right after this happens, I stop by Freddie the general manager's office. Nobody is running into high fives. There's not even a staff announcement on the PA saying they made it.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: I've got to say, it's weirdly anticlimactic.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: There's no hurrah. There's no balloons falling from the ceiling. We did our job. Everybody earned their paycheck. That's the bottom line.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And then the clock starts ticking tomorrow morning on next month?

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: We're all a bunch of losers tomorrow morning. You start all over again. That's how it goes. Oh, the wife. Oh, my god. Don't get married.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: We're fighting because I told-- she says to me, what time are you getting home? I said, what time do I usually get home at the end of the month? Whenever I get home. What, do you want a time card? What, am I in punching in?
